item.title: I’m the Secretary General of the Council of Europe. This Is Something I Thought I’d Never Have to Write.
item.description: International law is either universal or meaningless. Greenland will show which one we choose.
item.dc:creator: Alain Berset

media:content.media:description: The U.S. consulate in Nuuk, Greenland.

item.title: ‘Finding Her Edge,’ Plus 8 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: Another ice-skating romance premieres, and a reboot of “Star Search” comes to Netflix.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

media:content.media:description: Cale Ambrozic and Madelyn Keys in “Finding Her Edge.”

item.title: Trump Is Obsessed With Yesterday’s Energy. China Is Focused on the Future.
item.description: China isn’t just building gigantic amounts of power. Its businesses are reshaping technological foundations to electrify the world.
item.dc:creator: Dan Wang

item.title: No Corrections: Jan. 19, 2026
item.description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 19, 2026.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Chim Chim Cher-ee! Sweeps Stage a Comeback in London.
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 19, 2026.

item.title: Prince Harry’s Court Case Against Daily Mail Publisher: What to Know
item.description: A trial is set to begin on Monday in Harry’s case accusing Associated Newspapers of phone hacking and other unlawful activities. Other claimants include Elton John and Liz Hurley.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

media:content.media:description: Prince Harry leaving the High Court in London after giving evidence. He has pursued several legal battles aimed at holding Britain’s tabloids to account over unlawful news gathering.

item.title: As Davos Convenes, Deference to Trump Has Replaced Everything
item.description: The traditional rhetoric of the World Economic Forum centered on global integration, climate change and international cooperation. Not anymore.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman

media:content.media:description: Attendees at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, last year.

item.title: Why Are New Zealanders Moving to Australia? More Money, Better Vibes.
item.description: More than 1 percent of New Zealand’s population left over the year ending in October. Many of the migrants were chasing salaries and opportunities in neighboring Australia.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Tatsiana Chypsanava

media:content.media:description: Travelers at Wellington International Airport, in New Zealand last month.

item.title: What Vietnam’s Communist Party Congress Hopes to Achieve
item.description: One of Asia’s most dynamic nations is weighing how to balance government control with raising per capita G.D.P. by about 70 percent in five years.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Tung Ngo

media:content.media:description: Signage for the 14th Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam outside the National Convention Center in Hanoi this month.

item.title: What We Know About the Deadly High-Speed Train Crash in Spain
item.description: The collision, caused by the derailment of one of the trains, was the deadliest in Spain since at least 2013.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim

media:content.media:description: A person affected by a deadly train derailment is transferred for treatment to the Caseta Municipal in Adamuz, Spain, on Sunday.

item.title: Guatemala Declares State of Emergency to Address Gang Violence
item.description: The country has seen a surge of unrest in recent days, including uprisings at prisons and the killing of police officers, which the authorities have blamed on gangs.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

media:content.media:description: Guatemalan riot police officers guard the entrance to the men’s Preventive Detention Center in Guatemala City on Sunday.

item.title: ‘A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms’ Season 1 Premiere Recap: A Tall Tale
item.description: The latest and most humorous offering in the “Game of Thrones” universe follows the hulking, lovable Ser Duncan, who may or may not be a real knight.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.category: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms (TV Program)

media:content.media:description: Peter Claffey as Ser Duncan the Tall in the premiere of “A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms.”

item.title: Live Updates: Trains Collide After Derailment in Spain, Killing at Least 21
item.description: A high-speed train smashed into another train after derailing in the southern province of Córdoba, officials said. The cause of the accident was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: One Month Later, CBS Airs Postponed ‘60 Minutes’ Report With Few Changes
item.description: A 13-minute segment about Venezuelan men deported by the Trump administration had been pulled at the last minute by CBS News’s editor in chief, Bari Weiss.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum

media:content.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The report featured the stories of Venezuelan men deported by the Trump administration to a prison in El Salvador.

item.title: China’s Birthrate Plunges to Lowest Level Since 1949
item.description: China’s population fell for a fourth straight year and its birthrate tumbled as policymakers failed to slow a demographic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson

media:content.media:description: Despite sweeping efforts to boost births, China’s population has shrunk and aged for a fourth straight year as deaths again outnumbered births.

item.title: Real Estate Crash Weighs on China’s Economic Growth
item.description: Falling apartment prices have erased the savings of millions of Chinese households, but exports lifted the economy to 5 percent growth last year.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher

media:content.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: China is still grappling with a property market crash that began four years ago, after many years of overbuilding.

item.title: Descarrilamiento en España: hay al menos 10 muertos
item.description: La colisión sucedió tras descarrilar los vagones traseros de un tren en el sur del país.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista

media:content.media:description: Trabajadores de emergencia en la escena del siniestro tras el descarrilamiento de dos trenes en Adamuz, España, el domingo.

item.title: San Francisco Mourns Its Beloved Alligator, Claude
item.description: The 30-year-old albino resident of the California Academy of Sciences died last month. On Sunday, thousands paid tribute.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight and Poppy Lynch

media:content.media:description: A nearly life-size sourdough loaf depicting Claude, the albino alligator who died last month, was created by Boudin Bakery, in San Francisco.

item.title: Deadly Train Crash in Spain
item.description: Emergency responders worked to evacuate survivors from the wreckage of a deadly crash between two high-speed trains that derailed in Adamuz, Spain, on Sunday.

item.title: In Minneapolis, a Pattern of Misconduct Toward Protesters
item.description: Legal and criminal justice experts said a ruling by a federal judge last week revealed conduct by immigration agents that evokes the civil rights era.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents hold down a protester outside the Whipple federal building in Minneapolis on Jan. 11.

item.title: Josh Shapiro Writes That Harris Team Asked if He Had Ever Been an Israeli Agent
item.description: In his new memoir, the Pennsylvania governor suggests that when Kamala Harris’s team vetted him to be her running mate, aides focused on Israel to an extent he found offensive.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A new memoir by Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania goes into detail about his experience being vetted to be former Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate in 2024.

item.title: European Union Officials Lean Toward Negotiating, Not Retaliating, Over Trump Tariff Threat
item.description: European Union ambassadors held an emergency meeting on Sunday, and leaders from across the 27-nation bloc will meet in Brussels later this week.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Anushka Patil

media:content.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The flag of Greenland flying outside the Danish Parliament on Friday.

item.title: Man Acquitted of Shining a Laser at Marine One With Trump Aboard
item.description: A jury found the man, Jacob Samuel Winkler, not guilty after just 35 minutes of deliberation. He was charged in September with pointing a laser at an aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.category: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

media:content.media:description: A Washington man was charged in September with pointing a laser at Marine One, the presidential helicopter, while President Trump was aboard.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 19, 2026
item.description: Find your “aha!” moment in Peter Gorman’s puzzle.
item.dc:creator: Jo Firestone

media:content.media:description: May this puzzle light up your brain.

item.title: A Century of The New York Times in Antarctica
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong takes a trip into the New York Times archives to see how our understanding of Antarctica has changed over the past century.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Kassie Bracken, Christina Thornell, David Seekamp, Stephanie Swart, Phil Caller, Chang W. Lee and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: Ralph Towner, Eclectic Guitarist With the Ensemble Oregon, Dies at 85
item.description: A composer and pianist as well, he was a prolific recording artist who integrated jazz, classical and world music traditions in a career that spanned seven decades.
item.dc:creator: Hank Shteamer

media:content.media:description: Mr. Towner in about 1976. He took up the guitar after seeing a fellow student playing a Bach piece on it. He later moved to Vienna, where he studied with a renowned Austrian guitarist and teacher.

item.title: Wilbur Wood, Ironman Knuckleballer for the White Sox, Is Dead at 84
item.description: He threw more innings in a season than any player since 1917. A three-time All-Star, he also had four 20-win seasons.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

media:content.media:description: Wilbur Wood pitching for the Chicago White Sox in 1974. He mastered the knuckleball with help from one of the greatest knuckleballers, Hoyt Wilhelm.

item.title: Noem Denies Use of Chemical Agents in Minnesota Protests, Then Backtracks
item.description: Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, said officers had not used pepper spray and similar measures limited by a judge’s order, then was confronted with a video that showed chemical agents deployed.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim

media:content.media:description: Kristi Noem, the secretary of homeland security, at the White House last week.

item.title: Trump’s Ultimatum to Europe
item.description: Trump threatened heavy tariffs on countries standing between him and Greenland. E.U. leaders are scrambling for a response.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times

item.title: Islamic Scholar’s Post-Sept. 11 Convictions Are Tossed on Free Speech Grounds
item.description: Federal judges ruled that an Islamic teacher’s statements goading men in Virginia to join an overseas militant group were protected by the First Amendment.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

media:content.media:description: Ali al-Tamimi, center, outside a courthouse in Alexandria, Va., during his trial in 2005, had his remaining convictions tossed out 20 years later.

item.title: Trump
item.description: Los países europeos dependen de Estados Unidos para la seguridad de la OTAN, lo que limita sus opciones. Su respuesta más contundente podrían ser represalias con su propia “bazuca” comercial.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

media:content.media:credit: Juliette Pavy para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Una protesta contra el presidente Trump en Nuuk, la capital de Groenlandia, el sábado.

item.title: Joe Montgomery, Who Made Bicycles Lighter, Dies at 86
item.description: A founder of Cannondale, he was among the first in the U.S. to mass-produce bikes frames out of large-diameter aluminum tubes, replacing heavier steel.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: Los incendios en Chile causan al menos 18 muertes
item.description: Un alcalde suplicó ayuda al gobierno nacional mientras las llamas destruían barrios enteros en la sureña región del Biobío.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and John Bartlett

media:content.media:description: Construcciones afectadas por el fuego en la región de Biobío en Chile el domingo.

item.title: Springsteen Denounces ICE Deployments and Renee Good’s Killing
item.description: In a surprise appearance in New Jersey, the musician dedicated his song “The Promised Land” to Ms. Good, who was killed by an ICE agent in Minneapolis this month.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

media:content.media:description: Bruce Springsteen performing in Los Angeles in October.

item.title: Tina Packer, Powerhouse of Shakespeare Performance, Dies at 87
item.description: She was a founder and the longtime artistic director of Shakespeare & Company, a repertory theater in western Massachusetts, and directed all his plays.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Tina Packer in 2017. “I wanted to set up a company that could be like Shakespeare’s company,” she said.

item.title: Top Editor at Axel Springer Is Ousted After Workplace Investigation
item.description: Jan Philipp Burgard was one of Axel Springer’s most prominent editors, overseeing its influential German broadsheet Welt.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin

media:content.media:credit: Hannes P Albert/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Jan Philipp Burgard in Berlin in June. He had said in a social media post that he had decided to resign after experiencing “a serious physical incident” on a flight back from vacation.

item.title: Chile Wildfires Kill 16 and Force Wide Evacuation
item.description: One mayor pleaded with the national government for help as flames destroyed entire neighborhoods in the southern region of Biobío.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and John Bartlett

media:content.media:description: Buildings damaged by wildfires in Chile’s Biobío region on Sunday.

item.title: Esto es lo que realmente quieren los venezolanos
item.description: Llevamos mucho tiempo enfrentándonos a una paradoja brutal: un Estado ausente pero omnipotente.
item.dc:creator: Colette Capriles
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Syrian Government and Kurdish-Led Force Agree to Merge After Clashes
item.description: The new deal also calls for a cease-fire. Government forces have taken strategic assets from the militia in recent days, weakening the force.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:description: Syrian Army personnel celebrated as government forces entered the northern city of Raqqa on Sunday.

item.title: Pentagon Tells 1,500 Troops to Prepare for Possible Deployment to Minnesota
item.description: But President Trump has already backed away from a threat to invoke the Insurrection Act in response to protests against the killing of a woman by a federal immigration agent.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis last week. The use of military force on domestic soil in the United States is rare, and it is usually reserved only for the most extreme situations.

item.title: Edna Lewis’s Biscuit Recipe and More Sunday Treats
item.description: Edna Lewis’s biscuits, served warm with butter and your favorite jam, are a lovely Sunday breakfast.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Ko

media:content.media:credit: Romulo Yanes for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Vivian Lui.
media:content.media:description: Edna Lewis’s biscuits, adapted by Francis Lam.

item.title: Trump’s Campaign Manager Resolves Daily Beast Defamation Suit
item.description: As part of the settlement, The Daily Beast was not required to apologize or issue any payment to Chris LaCivita, who sued the outlet last year.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Chris LaCivita, a former campaign manager for President Trump, at a session of Congress in March for an address by Mr. Trump.

item.title: Danes Feel Betrayed and Bewildered by Trump Amid Greenland Threats
item.description: The American president’s vow to get Greenland, the semiautonomous Danish territory, has thrown the tiny, pro-American Nordic nation into crisis.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Bumiller and Hilary Swift

media:content.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators gather at Råduspladsen, City Hall in Copenhagen on Saturday. People gathered in different cities in Denmark and Greenland to protest against US President Donald Trump’s designs to take over the Arctic island. The timing coinsided with a US delegations trip to Copenhagen.

item.title: $1 Billion in Cash Buys a Permanent Seat on Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’
item.description: The board was originally conceived to oversee the rebuilding of Gaza, but its charter does not mention the Palestinian enclave, suggesting a possibly broader mandate.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner

media:content.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gaza City, last week. About 80 percent of the buildings in Gaza have been damaged or destroyed, according to the United Nations.

item.title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Trump Recaps His Recent ‘Legal-ish’ Activities
item.description: The first episode of 2026, hosted by Finn Wolfhard of “Stranger Things,” satirized that hit Netflix series and conjured a Harry Potter reboot à la “Heated Rivalry.”
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff

item.title: When Indian Americans Feel Unwelcome
item.description: Readers discuss a column by Lydia Polgreen about how Indians are rethinking migration to America.

media:content.media:credit: Miraj Patel for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Indian immigrants in the United States have found success, and unexpected hostility.

item.title: Can ICE Do That?
item.description: Times reporters answer readers’ questions about immigration and deportation.
item.dc:creator: Adam B. Kushner

media:content.media:description: In Minneapolis.

item.title: Winter Storm Brings Snow and Cold Temps as Far South as Florida and Georgia
item.description: Snow fell as far south as Florida and Georgia on Sunday but mostly melted by the afternoon. The same storm system brought snow to the Northeast, with a second round expected Sunday night.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff

media:content.media:credit: John Blackie/Pensacola News Journal, via USA Today Network
media:content.media:description: Snow falling early on Sunday morning at a Hyundai dealership in Pensacola, Fla. Snow was also falling in parts of Georgia.

item.title: After Trump Reignites a Trade War Over Greenland, Europe Weighs Hitting Back
item.description: Europe’s dependence on the United States for NATO security limits its options. Its strongest response would be a trade “bazooka,” and other options are possible.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

media:content.media:credit: Juliette Pavy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A protest against President Trump in Nuuk, the capital of Greenland, on Saturday.

item.title: An Old Theory Helps Explain What Happened to Renee Good
item.description: She had no way of knowing she had crossed a line.
item.dc:creator: David French
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
